section.name: RMIIO Class Reference
section.p: The large number of classes in the RMIIO package may initially be a bit daunting. The reference below describes the primary classes that users of this library will likely use.

subsection.name: RemoteInputStream
subsection.p: Probably the first class anyone will use from RMIIO is a RemoteInputStream. When a RemoteInputStream is utilized to move data across the network, it is essentially using a pull based approach, as the consumer of the stream pulls the data from the producer. The actual implementations are:

ul.li: SimpleRemoteInputStream - RemoteInputStream implementation which does not use any compression on the wire. This may be useful if the client and server are on the same box, or network bandwidth is not an issue.

GZIPRemoteInputStream - RemoteInputStream implementation which uses GZIP compression over the wire. For moving data of any non-trivial size, this is probably the preferred implementation. Note that it does trade off some extra CPU usage on the client and server for the reduction in network bandwidth.

Note that the "Client" and "Server" objects are named based on who initiates the RPC interaction, but that the actual RPC calls go both ways.

subsection.name: RemoteOutputStream
subsection.p: A RemoteOutputStream turns the tables with respect to a RemoteInputStream, as it is essentially uses a push based approach. The producer of the data pushes the data to the consumer. The actual implementations are:

ul.li: SimpleRemoteOutputStream - RemoteOutputStream implementation which does not use any compression on the wire. This may be useful if the client and server are on the same box, or network bandwidth is not an issue.

GZIPRemoteOutputStream - RemoteOutputStream implementation which uses GZIP compression over the wire. For moving data of any non-trivial size, this is probably the preferred implementation. Note that it does trade off some extra CPU usage on the client and server for the reduction in network bandwidth.
